bestBHT.bht: The man suddenly raised his voice above the tone in which he was speaking, catching the attention of the crowd. The miracle of the lame man leaping up and walking upright was a display of newfound power and glad consciousness. It was not only a physical healing, but also a testimony to the readiness and willingness to obey God. The apostles, in performing miracles, sought to magnify the name of Christ and ascribe the virtue of the miracle to Him. This powerful act of healing, concealed by the usual English rendering, demonstrated the authority and transformative power of Jesus.

Henry Alford: 10. with a loud voice] The original implies that he suddenly raised his voice above the tone in which he was before speaking.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 8-10. there sat there a certain man
. . . a cripple from his mother's womb . . . The same heard Paul
speak—in the open air and ( :-) to a crowd of people.
Albert Barnes: Said with a loud voice - See the notes on John 11:43.
And he leaped - See the notes on Acts 3:8. Compare Isaiah 35:6.
Marvin Vincent: Compare made straight, Luke 13:13, and see note there.
Leaped. Better, as Rev., leaped up. Note the aorist tense, indicating a single act, while the imperfect, walked, denotes continuous action.
John Calvin: I say to thee in the name of Jesus Christ."
The apostles were careful to magnify the name of Christ in all miracles.
The lame man leapt up, it serveth not only for the commendation of God’s power, but also such readiness and willingness to obey did testify that he was rightly prepared by the Lord.
Philip Schaff: The lame man sprang up in his glad consciousness of a new power he had never felt before.

O strange miracle! Not only could he stand upright, he who ever since his child-days had sat and reclined, but he could now move and walk like other men whom he had for so many years watched and longed to imitate.
Such criticism passes over such marked differences in the two incidents as the following.
Archibald T. Robertson: Upright (ορθος). Predicate adjective. In this sense Galen and Hippocrates frequently use ορθος (erect, straight).
He leaped up and walked (ηλατο κα περιεπατε). Rather, He leaped up with a single bound and began to walk.
This graphic picture is concealed by the usual English rendering.
John Gill: Said with a loud voice,.... Not only that the man, but that all might hear and attend to the miracle about to be wrought.
I say unto thee, in the name of the Lord Jesus Christ; which is much such a form that Peter used, Acts 3:6 whereby the virtue of the miracle is ascribed to Christ, and not assumed by the apostle.
He leaped and walked; he sprung up directly from his seat, and leaped about for joy, and walked as well as any other man could.

bhtAttempts.bht: The man suddenly raised his voice above the tone in which he was speaking, catching the attention of the crowd. The miracle of the lame man leaping up and walking upright was a display of newfound power and glad consciousness. It was not only a physical healing, but also a testimony to the readiness and willingness to obey God. The apostles, in performing miracles, sought to magnify the name of Christ and ascribe the virtue of the miracle to Him. This powerful act of healing, concealed by the usual English rendering, demonstrated the authority and transformative power of Jesus.

With a sudden increase in volume, the man's voice rose above the crowd as he spoke. The miracle of the lame man leaping up and walking upright was a remarkable display of new-found power and joy. This act not only showed physical healing, but also revealed a readiness and willingness to obey God. The apostles sought to magnify the name of Christ and ascribe the virtue of the miracle to Him. Through this powerful act, the authority and transformative power of Jesus were revealed.

The apostles aimed to magnify the name of Christ in all miracles, attributing the virtue of the miracle to Him. This powerful act showcased the authority and transformative power of Jesus.
